title: 114_hr5974
content: The Act may be cited as the "Coptic Churches Accountability Act". It includes findings related to the accountability of Coptic Churches. In August 2013, Islamist-led mobs burned and destroyed Christian properties in Egypt after the government led by the Muslim Brotherhood was removed. The succeeding government, under President Sisi, announced that the army would rebuild the damaged churches at government expense. President Sisi also made an appearance at a Coptic Christian Christmas liturgy in January 2015. President Sisi pledged to swiftly repair all affected churches in Egypt, acknowledging the historical and national role of the Coptic community. He made this commitment during a Christmas liturgy in January 2016, apologizing for the delay in renovating churches damaged during the 2013 sectarian violence. The Egyptian military and private citizens have restored a total of 49 out of 78 churches and Christian buildings damaged in the August 2013 sectarian violence. 29 buildings in 24 locations still need to be restored as of September 6, 2016. Additionally, a new law passed in August 2016 imposes significant burdens on church construction in Egypt. In August 2013, sectarian violence damaged 78 churches and Christian buildings in Egypt. Private citizens have restored 23 buildings, leaving 29 buildings in 24 locations still needing restoration as of September 6, 2016. A new law passed in August 2016 imposes burdens on church construction. In El-`Our, Minya, protests occurred in March 2015 against the building of a new church in honor of Egyptian Christians beheaded by Da'esh militants in Libya. President Sisi approved the construction in response to calls by Coptic Orthodox Church leaders. Protests erupted against the construction of a new church in honor of Egyptian Christians beheaded by Da'esh militants in Libya. Villagers besieged the existing church, armed protestors threw Molotov cocktails, set fire to a Christian-owned vehicle, and attacked another Christian's house. Egyptian government officials engage in reconciliation sessions to address sectarian violence incidents. The Coptic Church, representing the largest Christian community in the Middle East, has faced sectarian violence in Egypt. Reconciliation sessions led by government officials have often favored the majority, hindering minorities' access to justice. United States diplomatic efforts play a role in addressing these issues. The Coptic Church, the largest Christian community in the Middle East, has faced sectarian violence in Egypt. United States diplomatic leadership contributes significantly to protecting religious minorities and their faith-based practices globally. The United States promotes religious freedom as a fundamental right and priority value in its engagement with other countries, recognizing it as essential for democracy and individual liberty. SEC. 3. REPORT. The Secretary of State must provide a report on the progress of restoring Christian religious property in Egypt after sectarian violence in August 2013 to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations every year until 2021. The Secretary of State must report on discussions with Egypt regarding the restoration of Christian property, implementation of laws for church construction, and Egyptian policies on building Christian churches. This information will be included in annual Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for Egypt. The Secretary of State will ensure that annual Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for Egypt include a summary of discussions on the construction of Christian churches and a list of Christian religious properties. The curr_chunk requires submission of a summary of information on Christian religious properties damaged during sectarian violence in August 2013.
